In order to investigate the possible toxic effects of chemicals on organisms living in rivers, scientists collected water samples from locations downstream of four factories that released wastewater into a river.

The scientists established six treatment groups of bulbs of the common onion, Allium cepa, to which they added clean freshwater, an aqueous solution of <math alttext="300 millimolar" overflow="scroll"> <mn>300 mM</mn> </math> mutagen <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>, or a water sample from one of the four river locations (<math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> through <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></math>). Mutagen <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is a compound that causes chromosomal mutations. After incubating the bulbs for <math alttext="24" overflow="scroll"><mn>24</mn></math> hours, the scientists removed root tips emerging from the bulbs in each treatment group and examined individual root tip cells under a microscope.

The scientists examined <math alttext="6,000" overflow="scroll"><mn>6,000</mn></math> root tip cells from each slide and recorded both the total number of cells that were in some stage of mitosis and the total number of mitotic cells in which either the chromosomes or the mitotic arrangement of the chromosomes appeared to be abnormal (Table 1). They calculated the mitotic index, the percent of all cells examined that were in mitosis. The mitotic index of treatment groups <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> through <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn></math> was then determined relative to the mitotic index of cells in freshwater, which was set at <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn></math> (Figure 1).

Based on the data, provide reasoning to justify your prediction. Explain why the mitotic index of cells in a root tip might be altered by a mutation that affects the mitotic spindle.
